hero.name: Gabriel F. de Carvalho
hero.title: Gabriel F. de Carvalho
hero.subtitle: I don't pick projects by stack — I pick them by impact. I've built everything from critical APIs for the Brazilian Air Force to complete platforms that power entire universities. If it's complex, scalable, and needs to work under pressure, that's the kind of challenge I'm after.
hero.bullet1: I've built systems from scratch for education, government, and research institutions.
hero.bullet2: I deliver documented, tested code ready to scale — no spreadsheets, no workarounds.
hero.bullet3: My work comes with native observability, structured logs, and architecture built to last.

section1.title: Gabriel Fernandes de Carvalho
section1.subtitle: Backend Developer with experience in Laravel, NodeJS, Python, .NET, PHP and Java
section1.intro: Scroll to discover my skills and projects
section1.bio: I've been coding back-end for years using Laravel, Node.js, Python, .NET, and Java — but the stack is just a tool. What matters is solving real problems. At Fábrica de Tecnologias Turing (UniEVANGÉLICA), I coordinate systems serving thousands of users daily. I've collaborated with the Brazilian Air Force on critical projects and maintain academic repositories that became references.

summary.title: Professional summary
summary.paragraph1: My territory is back-end for systems that can't fail. Laravel, Node.js, Python, .NET, Java — I use whatever makes sense for each scenario. Relational databases are my foundation: MySQL, PostgreSQL, SQL Server, SQLite. But I'm not limited to that. If the project demands NoSQL, message brokers, or distributed architecture, I'm in.
summary.paragraph2: I build REST APIs that come with versioned OpenAPI contracts, automated test suites, and documentation any dev can understand. I work with enterprise SSO, message queues, webhooks, and integrations between legacy and modern systems. Security is a baseline requirement: I implement LGPD compliance by default, layered encryption, and auditable logs that survive any external audit. At Fábrica de Tecnologias Turing and FAB projects, I learned that good code is code another dev can maintain three years later without calling me at 2 AM.
summary.paragraph3: I collaborate directly with designers, product owners, and even legal when projects require it. I like releases that ship with clear metrics, documented SLAs, and observability from the first commit. My goal isn't just to deliver — it's to deliver something that scales, handles real traffic, and passes compliance without surprises.

jac.title: JAC – Academic and Community Journey
jac.impact: I centralized the university's entire event operation into a single platform. Automatic check-in via geolocation and QR Code, gamification to engage students, and executive dashboards showing real-time participation. Managers now make decisions looking at concrete numbers, not guessing how many people showed up to the event.
jac.roleShort: I architected from scratch, modeled event and attendance domains thinking about scalability, implemented the entire data protection layer according to LGPD, and delivered with complete documentation for the maintenance team to take over without depending on me.
jac.result: System in production with dashboards used weekly by senior management.

fanstone.title: James Fanstone System
fanstone.impact: I organized the entire institutional research workflow with end-to-end auditable approvals. Integration with Lyceum cut out that absurd data duplication and manual registration errors that delayed processes for weeks. Now everything is traceable, from initial protocol to final report.
fanstone.roleShort: I modeled the system domain from stakeholder meetings, created robust REST APIs in Laravel with multi-level authentication, and implemented integrations that talk to 15-year-old systems. I validated each workflow with research staff in practical testing sessions.
fanstone.result: System running in production with unanimous approval from the research team.

esports.title: Portal 3rd E-Sports UniEVANGÉLICA
esports.impact: I created a portal where any student can see the complete tournament schedule and register directly from their phone, without printing anything or sending emails to confirm. That whole bureaucracy that made organizers waste days just managing registrations is gone.
esports.roleShort: I developed the entire responsive front-end using modular SCSS, implemented client-side validations that prevent input errors, and structured the code with accessibility in mind from the start. I worked side by side with designers to ensure the visual experience was flawless on any device.
esports.result: Portal ran throughout the tournament without a single support ticket.

ftt.bullet1: I built complete REST APIs with Node.js and TypeScript, versioned contracts in OpenAPI 3.0, and documented everything so other devs could integrate without calling me on Slack for every question.
ftt.bullet2: I implemented integrations using RabbitMQ and internal SSO with OAuth2, optimized PostgreSQL queries that were killing the database, and kept latency below 200ms even under heavy load.
ftt.bullet3: I review team code weekly and structured logs with correlationID to track requests from start to finish — essential when something breaks in production at 3 PM.

proppe.bullet1: I modeled complex research approval workflows using Laravel with PostgreSQL, automated stages that used to take weeks, and created auditable trails that actually work in external audits.
proppe.bullet2: I integrated Lyceum and legacy ERPs through secure REST APIs with retry logic and dead letter queues — zero data loss, fewer human errors, processes that run themselves.
proppe.bullet3: I built interactive dashboards with Vue.js for managers and researchers to see the status of everything in real-time. Nobody needs to send emails asking 'where's my process?' anymore.

fab.bullet1: I developed a complete availability control API in .NET 6 with JWT authentication, granular profile control, and traceability in every operation — baseline requirement in a military environment.
fab.bullet2: I configured CI/CD pipelines with automated tests, coverage above 80%, and Swagger documentation that passed all internal audits without revision.
fab.bullet3: I implemented structured logs in Elasticsearch with alerts configured in Kibana. When something goes off track, the team gets alerts before end users complain.
